Project Description  The  Project  is  formulated  as  a  sector  loan  to  support  the 
Government’s sector investment plan for 22 secondary towns. To 
be  included  in  the  Project,  municipalities  (Pourashavas)  are 
required to implement an Urban Governance Improvement Action 
Program (UGIAP). Initially, Pourashavas will be given limited funds 
to cover the most urgent investment requirements.  The continuing 
participation in the sector Project, however, will depend on the 
actual progress made with the implementation of the UGIAP by the 
participating  municipalities.  This  suggests  a  significant 
improvement from the previous approach, in which all investment 
components were predetermined at the time of project appraisal 
and the participating Pourashavas were left unaccountable for their 
performance  during  project  implementation.  The  blueprint 
approach adopted in the past has clearly failed in its commitment 
to bring about sustainable improvements in urban management 
because  of  the  basically  supply-driven  nature  of  resource 
allocation.  Thus,  a  performance-based  sector  approach  is 
employed under the Project, involving demand-driven allocation of 
loan proceeds that is based on clearly defined performance criteria 
and the commitment to undertake governance reform. 
 
Rationale  Recent  experience  in  Bangladesh  suggests  that  urbanization 
needs to be seen in a positive light. The poverty reducing potential 
of  well-planned  and  decentralized  urbanization  is  immense, 
especially  in  the  longer  term.  However,  unplanned  and 
uncontrolled urbanization creates tremendous pressure on basic 
urban infrastructure and eventually limits the growth potential of the 
national economy. Moreover, the concentration of population and 
activities in a few metropolitan areas tends to further aggravate 
urban  environmental  conditions  in  the  absence  of  adequate 
capacities to manage urban growth. Recognizing diseconomies of 
congestion and environmental degradation in metropolitan cities, 
the  Government  has  requested  ADB  to  continue  to  provide 
assistance to the urban sector for rehabilitation and expansion of 
urban development and services in Pourashavas throughout the 
country, and to further assist in decentralization and strengthening 
of urban governance.

iv 
Objectives and Scope  The Project will assist the selected Pourashavas to (i) enhance 
accountability  in  municipal  management  and  strengthen 
capabilities in the provision of municipal services, and (ii) develop 
and expand physical infrastructure and urban services to increase 
economic  opportunities,  and  to  reduce  vulnerability  to 
environmental  degradation,  poverty,  and  natural  hazards.  The 
Project will also promote the active participation of women citizens 
in municipal management and services as well as upgrade the 
conditions of the poorest and most needy groups in the slum area. 
 
  The Project comprises three parts: Part A, Urban Infrastructure 
Improvement, covers the improvement/expansion of the following 
municipal infrastructure facilities: (i) roads and bridges, (ii) storm 
water  drainage,  (iii)  low-cost  sanitation,  (iv)  solid  waste 
management, (v) municipal facilities (e.g., bus and truck terminals, 
kitchen markets, and slaughterhouses) and (vi) slum improvement. 
Under  specific  circumstances  inclusion  of  water  supply 
rehabilitation schemes will also be considered. 
   
Part B, Urban Governance Improvement, includes implementation 
of an action program in five key result areas: (i) citizen awareness 
and participation; (ii) women’s participation; (iii) integration of the 
urban poor; (iv) financial accountability and sustainability; and (v) 
administrative  transparency.  In  each  of  these  five  areas,  the 
Pourashavas will need to achieve well-defined performance targets 
that  will  be  closely  monitored  and  evaluated  during  project 
implementation. 
   
Part C, Capacity Building and Implementation Assistance, covers 
(i) project management, detailed engineering design, construction 
supervision, nongovernment organization support to community-
based activities, and facilitation of community mobilization; and (ii) 
institutional  capacity-building  programs  for  Pourashavas  to 
successfully  implement  the  UGIAP,  including  (a)  an  orientation 
program for Pourashava chairpersons and ward commissioners, 
(b) a tailored program for female ward commissioners, (c) training 
programs for municipal secretaries to implement the community-
based  activities  under  the  UGIAP,  (d)  computerization  of  tax 
records  and  billing,  (e)  computerization  of  accounting 
management, (f) infrastructure inventory assessment and mapping,  
and (g) training for decentralized township planning.

Implementation Period  Based  on  the  experience  of  Secondary  Towns  Infrastructure 
and Startup Activities  Development I and II, and in view of the sector modality of the 
Project,  and  the  large  number  and  geographical  spread  of 
participating Pourashavas, the Project will be implemented over a 
period of 6 years. Implementation is expected to commence in the 
second quarter of 2003. Start-up activities (after Loan Approval) 
will  include  the  following:  (i)  establishment  of  the  national  and 
regional UMSUs (LGED); (ii) recruitment of project staff for the 
PMO  and  PIUs  (LGED  and  Pourashavas);  (iii)  selection  and 
recruitment  of  consultants  (LGED);  (iv)  preparation  of  strategic 
development vision (Pourashavas); (v) preparation of subproject 
appraisal  reports  for  the  Phase  1  work  program  (LGED  and 
Pourashavas);  and  (vi)  procurement  of  immediately  required 
equipment (LGED). Physical works may not start before the fourth 
quarter of 2003 due to the need to undertake extensive surveys 
and prepare detailed engineering designs and contract documents. 
   
Project Benefits and  All current 1,836,000 citizens of the project towns, representing 
Beneficiaries  around 6% of the total urban population are expected to benefit, 
directly or indirectly, from the Project. This will be achieved mainly 
through  improvement  of  basic  urban  infrastructure  facilities 
including roads (400 kilometers [km] and at least 25 bridges) and 
drainage systems (260 km). Regarding the latter, it is expected that 
around  650,000  people  will  benefit  from  reduced  flooding  and 
greater  productivity.  Particular  attention  will  also  be  given  to 
improving  the  living  conditions  of  the  urban  poor  (estimated 
120,000  people  or  around  7%  of  the  beneficiaries),  through 
community-based  environmental  improvement  works  and  slum 
improvement activities. Further, the implementation of the Project 
will require almost 10,000 person-years of unskilled laborers of 
which at least one third will be women. Through the provision of 
microcredit,  income-generating  activities  will  be  supported  in 
particularly for women in low-income areas. 
 
  It is estimated that, upon completion of the Project (2009), around 
20,000 households will have improved domestic sanitary facilities, 
while  the  general  public  will  have  better  access  to  community 
toilets. Improved solid waste management (currently around 50% 
of the waste is collected and disposed of) will improve health and 
environmental  conditions.  The  planning  assumption  is  that,  in 
2011, all Pourashavas should have the facilities to reach a waste 
collection and disposal efficiency of at least 70%.  
 
Risks and Assumptions  While no unusual risks are foreseen during implementation, the 
potential risks concern (i) delays in implementation due to slow 
progress  with  start-up  activities;  (ii)  lack  of  suitably  qualified 
personnel in the Pourashavas which may eventually lead to weak 
implementation of subprojects at the Pourashava level; and (iii) 
sustainability  of  the  facilities  and  services  provided  under  the 
Project.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to  the  People’s  Republic  of  Bangladesh  for  the  Urban  Governance  and  Infrastructure 
Improvement (Sector) Project. The report also describes proposed technical assistance (TA) for 
Supporting Urban Governance Reform, and if the Board approves the proposed loan, I, acting 
under the authority delegated to me by the Board, will approve the TA. 
 
 
II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
 
2.  Recognizing diseconomies of congestion and environmental degradation in metropolitan 
cities,  the  Government  has  requested  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  to  continue  to 
provide assistance to the urban sector for rehabilitation and expansion of urban development 
and services in secondary towns (Pourashavas) throughout the country, and to further assist in 
the decentralization and strengthening of urban governance. In response, ADB provided two 
project preparatory technical assistance (PPTA)1 grants to undertake a feasibility study and 
project preparation. This Report is based on the findings of these PPTAs, and the discussions 
with all stakeholders during the TA review, loan fact-finding, and appraisal missions.2 The 
project framework is in Appendix 1, which summarizes the objectives, scope, and approach of 
the Project.  
 
A.  Urban Sector Performance Indicators and Analysis 
 
3.  Urbanization. In 2001, the total urban population in Bangladesh was about 30 million, 
representing approximately 23% of the national population. While this level of urbanization is 
relatively low by Asian standards, the urban population grew at an annual rate of about 3.5% in 
1991-2000, compared with the national population growth rate of 1.5%. The growth rates of 
Pourashavas range from relatively low in most (at around 2%), to moderately high (up to 4.5%) 
in a few cases. The growth of the urban population in Bangladesh is mainly due to the growth of 
metropolitan cities.  
 
4.  Contribution to Economic Growth. Rapid urbanization has contributed to the growing 
share of the urban sector in overall economic growth. Over 40% of the country's gross domestic 
product (GDP) is now derived from the urban sector, from a low of 25% in the early 1970s. The 
Government’s Fifth Five-Year Plan (1997-2002) projected that the urban sector GDP would 
grow at around 14% per annum, which is more than twice the growth target for the national 
GDP.    
 
5.  Urban Poverty. The incidence of poverty in Bangladesh, as measured by the costs of 
basic needs poverty line, fell from 58.8% in FY1992 to 49.8% in 2000. A sector breakdown 
shows that progress in reducing poverty was almost equal across urban and rural areas: the 
urban headcount ratio declined from 44.9% to 36.6% (by 8.3%) while rural poverty declined 
from 61.2% to 53.0% (by 8.2%). However, the moderate reduction in urban poverty during the 
last decade was accompanied by a notable increase in urban income inequality, as the Gini 
coefficient increased from 0.398 to 0.452.  
 
6.  The situations have been somewhat different in the case of absolute numbers of the 
poor in urban and rural areas. In FY1992, the number of urban poor population was 6.5 million 
when total urban population was 14.6 million. This then increased to 9.3 million in 2000. Thus 
there has been at least a 43% growth of the urban poor population during the last decade. The

7.  Urban Infrastructure and Basic Services.  There are deficiencies in all urban services. 
Only 30% of urban households use tap water for drinking, and probably less than 20% have 
their own house connections. With the exception of a limited waterborne sewerage system in 
Dhaka, no other urban center has any form of sewerage system. Solid waste collection levels 
are around 20%. Urban areas also suffer from severe traffic congestion and the absence of any 
form of mass public transit system. For most urban residents, housing conditions are very bad. 
Only 25% of urban households live in dwellings with permanent structure.  Very high land prices, 
insecurity of tenure, and a lack of housing finance have handicapped the growth of the formal 
sector of the housing market. In most urban centers, ambient air and water quality is extremely 
poor. The major sources of air pollution are traffic, brickfields, and industry. The major sources 
of water pollution are domestic and industrial wastewater discharges. Inadequate drainage 
increases the exposure of the urban population to the effects of polluted water.  
 
B.  Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 
 
  1.  Slow Progress in Policy and Institutional Reform 
 
8.  Recent experience in Bangladesh suggests that urbanization needs to be seen in a 
positive light. The poverty reducing potential of well-planned and decentralized urbanization is 
immense, especially in the longer term. However, unplanned and uncontrolled urbanization 
creates tremendous pressure on basic urban infrastructure and eventually limits the growth 
potential of the national economy. Moreover, the concentration of population and activities in a 
few  metropolitan  areas  tends  to  further  aggravate  urban  environmental  conditions  in  the 
absence of adequate capacity to manage urban growth (a summary of urban sector analysis is 
presented in Appendix 2).  
 
9.  The  Government  is  therefore  developing  secondary  towns  to  improve  their  living 
standards, particularly in the poorer areas, and to provide an alternative to those who would join 
the migration to the larger metropolitan cities. ADB has been assisting the Government to 
achieve these goals since 1990 through the Secondary Towns Infrastructure Development 
Projects  I  and  II3 (STIDP  I  and  II).  So  far,  ADB  has  supported  upgrading  of  municipal 
infrastructure facilities in 32 of 64 district towns in Bangladesh. The World Bank is currently 
covering another 14 district towns under its Municipal Services Project (external assistance in 
the sector is summarized in Appendix 3). With the implementation of the proposed Project, 
almost all district towns in Bangladesh will be provided with necessary financial and technical 
assistance to improve basic urban infrastructure and management of urban affairs.   
 
10.  The implementation of physical works under the past and ongoing projects has been 
satisfactory. However, the progress in institutional reform, an integral part of all urban projects, 
has  been  much  slower  than  originally  anticipated.  In  fact,  the  slow  progress  made  on 
institutional reform is a reflection of poor governance and lack of accountability on the side of 
the participating municipalities in urban management. Good urban governance and effective 
management are a prerequisite for well-functioning cities. Past experience shows that physical 
infrastructure improvement cannot be sustained unless the underlying governance problems are

  2.  Promoting Good Urban Governance 
 
11.  Urban governance is broadly defined as "the sum of the many ways individuals and 
institutions, public and private, plan and manage the common affairs of the city.”4 Two aspects 
of this broad definition need further elaboration. First, it indicates that urban governance is not 
just government. Governance as a concept recognizes that decision-making power to improve 
the  affairs  of  the  city  exists  inside  and  outside  the  formal  authority  and  institutions  of 
government. In other words, governance includes the government, private sector, and civil 
society.  The  second  aspect  emphasizes  that  urban  governance  is  a  "process."  It  is  a 
participatory process through which diverse interests of the city may be accommodated and 
cooperative action can be taken.  
 
12.  Through  extensive  interviews  and  consultations  with  the  Pourashavas  during  the 
implementation of the PPTA, it became evident that most of the Project towns have a poor 
record in terms of public participation in urban management. Promoting decentralization of 
authority and powers to Pourashavas will not produce any desirable result unless there is a 
commensurate increase in the delegation of powers from the Pourashava chairpersons to 
elected commissioners and to citizen groups. The key to the gains in efficiency associated with 
decentralization is the accountability of elected officials, especially the chairpersons, to local 
residents. Increasing accountability will require more participation of citizens in Pourashava 
affairs.  
 
13.  Overall,  there  are  two  outstanding  considerations  under  the  Project  for  improving 
Pourashava governance: First is a concern for the concentration of authority and powers in the 
hands of the Pourashava chairperson, which results in poor performance, inefficiency, and lack 
of accountability, much to the detriment of good governance. The second is a concern for weak 
capacity of elected commissioners, local public officials, and community groups; this becomes 
concern for the limited scope for increasing the role of municipal council, and ward and citizens 
committees in running municipal affairs.  
 
14.  To effectively address these main concerns, an Urban Governance Improvement Action 
Program (UGIAP) has been developed in close consultation with the participating Pourashavas. 
Overall, the UGIAP comprises five subprograms: three for enhancing the awareness and the 
participation of local stakeholders in urban planning and management (citizen awareness and 
participation, women’s participation, and integration of the urban poor) and two for improving 
accountability and transparency (financial accountability and sustainability, and administrative 
transparency). Under these subprograms, Pourashavas will be asked to form town-level citizens 
committees, develop participatory municipal development plan, strengthen the role of female 
ward  commissioners,  implement  poverty  reduction  action  programs,  operate  microcredit 
program for the poor women, and increase tax collection. 
 
15.  While the ultimate responsibility for urban governance rests with urban local bodies, the 
role of the Central Government is also important. On the fiscal side, the Central Government 
directly supports centrally funded municipal projects and has statutory control over different 
aspects of municipal revenues and expenditures. A central government ministry, Ministry of 
Local  Government,  Rural  Development  and  Cooperatives  (MLGRDC),  is  responsible  for 
supervision of municipal affairs, the scope of which includes demanding records, inspection of 
activities, and revoking illegal orders and decisions of municipal governments. Given the large 
number of the central government agencies involved in planning, building, and managing urban

III.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
 
A.  Objectives 
 
16.  The primary objective of the Project is to promote human development and good urban 
governance in secondary towns of Bangladesh. To achieve this objective, the Project will assist 
the  selected  Pourashavas  to  (i)  enhance  accountability  in  municipal  management  and 
strengthen their capabilities in the provision of municipal services; and (ii) develop and expand 
physical infrastructure and urban services to increase economic opportunities, and to reduce 
vulnerability to environmental degradation, poverty, and natural hazards. While the Project will 
benefit the entire urban community in general, some of its components will focus on upgrading 
the conditions of the poorest and most needy groups in the slum areas in particular. The Project 
will also promote active participation of women citizens in municipal management and services 
as both beneficiaries and agents.    
 
17.  The Project will use a performance-based sector loan approach. To be included in the 
Project,  municipalities  are  required  to  implement  the  UGIAP.  Initially,  all  participating 
Pourashavas will be given limited funds to cover the most urgent investment requirements.  The 
continuing participation in the sector Project, however, will depend on the actual progress made 
with the implementation of the UGIAP. This suggests a significant improvement from a previous 
approach  in  which  all  investment  components  were  predetermined  at  the  time  of  project 
appraisal and the participating Pourashavas were left unaccountable for their performance 
during project implementation. Such a blueprint approach adopted in the past has failed in its 
commitment to bring about sustainable improvements in urban management because of the 
basically supply-driven nature of resource allocation. Thus, an alternative approach is employed 
under the Project, involving demand-driven allocation of loan proceeds, which is based on 
clearly defined performance criteria and the commitment to undertake governance reform. 
 
B.  Sector Loan Approach     
 
18.  The Project is formulated as a sector loan based on the Government’s sector investment 
plan for Pourashavas and will support a 6-year time and area slice of the plan, representing 
28% of estimated investment during 2003-2009 and covering about 22 Pourashavas. Overall, 
the Project meets the criteria for adopting a sector lending modality:5 (i) there is a strong sector 
agency, namely LGED, which has successfully implemented a number of urban projects funded 
by both domestic and external resources; (ii) MLGRDC has adopted a comprehensive Urban 
Management Policy, which will guide urban development in the country; and (iii) a credible 
sector investment plan for Pourashavas (as provided in the Government’s Annual Development 
Plan) exists, which has successfully guided sector development so far.

improvement/expansion of the following municipal infrastructure facilities (i) roads and bridges,

  1.  Part A: Urban Infrastructure Improvement 
 
20.  Funds will be made available to the Pourashavas under Part A: Urban Infrastructure 
Improvement in three phases that coincide with performance under Part B: Urban Governance

eligible for financing under each subproject. 
 
    a.  Roads and Bridges 
 
21.  The component will include the improvement of the Pourashavas’ road networks and 
traffic circulation, largely through the rehabilitation, repair, and widening of existing roads within 
the urban core area, traffic management improvements, and procurement of equipment to keep 
the road system in a good condition.  
 
b.  Stormwater Drainage 
 
22.  The stormwater drainage improvements are intended to alleviate major inundation from 
rainfall and reduce waterlogging problems within the core urban area of the Pourashava. The 
works  include  (i)  elimination  of  all  blockages/obstructions  and  encroachments  on  existing 
drainage paths, (ii) cleaning and rehabilitation of existing drains, (iii) construction of new drains 
to serve previously unserviced areas, and (iv) construction of missing links.  
 
c.  Low-Cost Sanitation 
 
23.  The sanitation component comprises a program for the provision of double-vault pit 
latrines and the construction of public toilet blocks. It is proposed to construct a total of about 
12,000 household or private double-vault pit latrines, and 84 public toilets.

equipment for operation and maintenance. Given the widespread arsenic contamination of groundwater in the 
country, the implementation of any tubewell works will be strictly in line with the Government’s guidelines and 
standards for the development of deep tubewells. No shallow tubewell work will be undertaken under the Project 
due to possible arsenic contamination. If the scope of the water supply work exceeds normal rehabilitation of the 
system, the implementation of the water supply component may be referred to the Department of Public Health 
Engineering with LGED as an implementing agency.

d.  Solid Waste Management 
 
24.  This component will improve collection efficiencies to 70% of household wastes and 
95% of other (commercial, institutional, and hospital) wastes within the core urban areas, and 
ensure improved arrangements for disposal. The component will provide for the procurement of 
garbage  trucks,  pushcarts,  and  communal  concrete  garbage  bins  in  order  to  improve  the 
storage and collection of wastes. Landfill sites will be developed to facilitate controlled disposal 
of the waste. 
 
e.  Municipal Facilities 
 
25.  To promote economic and commercial development in the towns and encourage public-
private partnerships, it is proposed to construct, extend or rehabilitate bus terminals, kitchen 
markets, and slaughterhouses in the Pourashavas. In a Pourashava where there is an acute 
need for additional parking facilities for trucks, and where there is very limited land available, it 
is proposed to construct a truck terminal. 
 
 
f.  Slum Upgrading 
 
26.  A component for the provision of services to the urban poor will be implemented in each 
Pourashava. The component is expected to assist about 18,000 slum families (120,000 slum 
dwellers) through the improvement of overall living conditions using an integrated approach that 
includes provision of basic urban services (e.g., access, water supply, drainage, sanitation, and 
solid waste management), and supporting health and literacy development activities.  
 
2.  Part B: Urban Governance Improvement  
 
27.  Local level reform will be implemented through the UGIAP. In exchange for receiving 
financial assistance under the Project, Pourashavas will enter into a subproject agreement with 
the Government represented by LGED to implement the action program in five key result areas. 
The implementation of the UGIAP will be in three phases over 6 years. It will take 2 years to 
complete each phase. The receipt by Pourashavas of funds for subprojects under Part A: Urban 
Infrastructure Improvement during the second and third phases will depend on performance 
under Part B.  
 
a.  Phase 1 
 
28.  All 22 Pourashavas identified under the PPTA will be included in phase 1 and they will 
sign a subproject agreement with the Government to participate in phase 1. While undertaking 
the urban infrastructure improvement components for phase 1, the Pourashavas will be required 
to carry out various reform activities as stipulated in the UGIAP (Appendix 4), with assistance 
from LGED. The performance of the Pourashavas will be closely monitored by the Government 
and ADB to determine their eligibility for phase 2 of the Project. The investment ceiling for 
implementation of the urban infrastructure components in phase 1 is set at around 25-30% of 
the total investment requirement assessed for each Pourashava during the PPTA. During the 
field  visits  under  TA.  No  36907,  high  priority  investment  components  for  phase  1  (mainly 
rehabilitation work for roads and drainage systems) were identified and confirmed with the 
Pourashavas (Appendix 5).

    b.  Phase 2 
 
29.  At the end of phase 1, each Pourashava will be evaluated by the Government and ADB

budget (up to 40% of the total investment requirement assessed during the PPTA) for phase 2, 
while the partly satisfactory Pourashavas will be given a lower budget (up to 20% of the total 
investment required). Phase 2 will also be open to all Pourashavas under categories A and B 
that are not included under phase 1 and are satisfactory to the Government and ADB. Where a 
new Pourashava applies to participate in the Project, its application will be evaluated based on 
separate entry criteria (Appendix 4). The eligible Pourashavas will sign a subproject agreement 
with LGED to participate in phase 2, covering up to 20% of the total investment demand 
assessed by the PMO. The total number of Pourashavas covered under the second phase will 
not exceed 30.    
 
    c.  Phase 3 
 
30.  Finally, the entry into phase 3 will depend on the performance during the second phase. 
Only those Pourashavas, that maintain a fully satisfactory rating during phase 2 will proceed to 
the final phase to fully utilize the financial assistance offered through the Project for urban 
infrastructure improvements components. In this way, Pourashavas that were previously rated 
as partly satisfactory can enter phase 3 only after their performance has improved to the level of 
fully satisfactory. No new Pourashava will be admitted in phase 3. The eligible Pourashavas will 
enter into formal agreements with the Government to participate in phase 3.  
 
31.  For the successful implementation of the performance-based approach, the application 
of  performance  criteria  must  be  done  in  a  transparent  and  balanced  manner.  The  final

participating Pourashavas will be delegated to the Pourashava Performance Review Committee

V.  PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, AND RISKS 
 
A.  Major Benefits and Impacts 
 
1.  Gender and Social 
 
67.  The gender and social assessments under the Project (the Summary Poverty Reduction 
and Social Strategy is found in Appendix 13) have resulted in the preparation of (i) the GAP to 
address the need for active participation of women in urban planning and management as both 
beneficiaries  and  agents,  (ii)  the  resettlement  framework  for  the  population  that  may  be 
displaced or suffer loss of assets and/or income as a result of project implementation, and (iii) 
the indigenous peoples framework to ensure their full participation in the Project and to address 
potential risks to them. These frameworks provide guidelines to assess the gender and social 
impact of all subprojects, and any subproject not meeting these standards will not be eligible for 
financing.  
 
  2.  Economic and Financial 
 
68.  The  Project  will  generally  benefit  the  whole  of  the  urban  community,  and  some 
components will focus on upgrading the conditions of the poorest and most needy groups in the 
slum areas. The investments will result in substantial direct and indirect benefits, including 
improved urban environment, better health, and higher employment and income generation 
potential for the residents. Components for the first phase (roads and drainage rehabilitation) 
were evaluated by cost-benefit analysis as summarized in Appendix 14. Subprojects for which 
economic analysis was carried out yielded an average rate of return of 34.0% for the drainage 
component and 30.6% for the road component. Overall, phase 1 investments are economically 
viable, and sensitivity analyses show that the returns are robust. Financial analysis was carried 
out  for  the  only  revenue-generating  component,  namely,  the  water  supply  scheme  in 
Lakshmipur. The rate of return was estimated at 10.7%, which is above the weighted average 
cost of capital, estimated at 7.0%. For the second and third phase investments, the economic 
and financial analyses will be reported in the SPARs for review by ADB. In general, however, it

18 
is expected that most municipal subprojects to be financed under the Project will have high 
economic rates of return due to the severe deficiencies in most Pourashavas.  
 
  3.  Fiscal  
 
69.  The financial burden of the Project on local government finances will not be significant. 
As most funding will be made available as grants to the Pourashavas, the debt service impact 
on local governments will be small. On the other hand, implementation of the Project will create 
employment opportunities, increase urban productivity, improve the management of municipal 
finances, mobilize more revenue, and rationalize municipal spending.  The net fiscal impact of 
these improvements is expected to substantially outweigh project investments.  
 
  4.  Environmental  
 
70.  The Project has been assigned environmental assessment category B. Overall, it is 
anticipated to have positive environmental impacts in reducing incidences of various diseases, 
improving environmental conditions in urban areas, and reducing flooding. The negative impacts 
will mostly relate to construction activities, which will be temporary, during construction only. 
Other potential negative impacts, such as groundwater contamination from sanitary landfills and 
disposal of sludge from latrines, can be addressed by applying proper environmental and 
sanitary engineering technologies during the design, construction, and operation stages. For 
evaluation purposes, sample initial environmental examinations (IEEs) have been conducted for 
subprojects with the highest potential environmental impacts in accordance with environmental 
requirements and ADB's guidelines for infrastructure projects.16 
 
71.  For subprojects that are still to be confirmed, the IEE will be prepared in accordance with 
ADB's  guidelines  for  infrastructure  projects.  For  construction,  compliance  with  government 
environmental requirements as certified by the relevant government authorities will be sufficient 
for typical subproject components costing less than $1 million.17 For subproject components 
costing between $1 million and $3 million, ADB will review and approve the IEEs on a "no 
objection" basis. For subproject components costing more than $3 million, ADB will review IEEs 
prior to the start of construction. 
   
5.  Technical  
 
72.  The majority of works under the Project are relatively small. These schemes were 
identified  based  on  the  needs  and  priorities  of  the  Pourashavas  in  consultation  with  the 
communities.  The  works  under  the  Project  do  not  require  complex  design  or  construction 
techniques, and are within the technical capabilities of the Pourashavas. LGED will provide 
additional technical support as considered necessary and will supervise the quality of the works 
of the Pourashavas. Engineering designs for the phase 1 works have been reviewed by the 
PPTA consultants. Design and supervision consultants will further review the designs to assure 
technical quality and timeliness.

suitably  qualified  personnel  in  the  Pourashavas,  which  may  eventually  lead  to  weak

SUMMARY OF URBAN SECTOR ANALYSIS 
 
A.  Demographic and Spatial Trends 
 
1.  Bangladesh has experienced significant growth in urban population from less than 5 
million in 1971 to almost 30 million in 2001. Accordingly, the level of urbanization increased from 
below 8% in 1971 to 23% in 2001. The growth in the number of urban centers has also been 
phenomenal, from under 100 in 1971 to 522 in 1991 (and most likely to be more than 550 in 
2001). There has also been growth in the number of large urban centers: Cities with more than 
100,000 population have grown in number from 5 in 1971 to 25 in 2001. There were no “million 
cities” in Bangladesh in 1961; now there are three, with Dhaka emerging as a megacity with 
nearly 10 million people in its greater Statistical Metropolitan Area.  
 
2.  Although Bangladesh presents a unique case of dispersal of urban centers almost in 
uniform density throughout the country (with the exception of the Chittagong Hill Tracts), the 
distribution is far from being a balanced one by city size. Certain regions suffer from the 
absence of large metropolitan centers, which could play the role of regional magnets or growth 
poles, and somewhat reduce the strong pull effect of Dhaka. Another spatial pattern in urban 
development in Bangladesh is the recent emergence of a corridor form of urban expansion, 
radiating from Dhaka towards the west, north, northeast, and east, following the highways, and 
to the southeast along the water routes. Railways have played a complementary role to roads in 
the northern and northeastern corridors. 
 
B.  Institutional Framework 
 
3.  In terms of administrative structure, urban centers in Bangladesh are classified as city 
corporations, Pourashavas (municipalities), and “other urban areas” (which are run under the 
union parishad system). The present number of city corporations is 4 (Dhaka, Chittagong, 
Khulna, and Rajshahi), with two more Pourashavas to be upgraded to city corporations (Sylhet 
and Barisal), while the number of Pourashavas is now over 250 (growing from less than 120 in 
1996).  Municipal  governments  include  city  corporations  and  pourashavas.  All  municipal 
governments operate within the limits set by relevant ordinances and acts. For instance, the 
Pourashava Ordinance of 1977 lays down the foundation of pourashavas and their functions, 
while similar ordinances define the role, power, and responsibilities of the city corporations. 
Besides the city corporations and pourashavas, some special development authorities and 
special purpose authorities were created to meet the growing demand for services based on two 
other ordinances − the Town Improvement Act of 1953 and the Sewerage Authority Ordinance 
of 1963. 
 
4.  Corporations  and  Pourashavas  have  an  elected  head  (mayor  for  corporations  and 
chairperson for Pourashavas) and a council of commissioners who represent the people in each 
suburb  or  ward,  and  are  mandated  by  ordinance  to  provide  urban  services  including  (i) 
maintenance of roads, drainage, and parks; (ii) operation of water supply systems, community 
toilets, markets, solid waste management, and slaughterhouses; (iii) delivery of public health 
and basic services for the urban poor; and (iv) development and building control. The executive 
power of a municipality rests with its chairperson or mayor who is the primary decision-maker. 
The chief executive officer is appointed by the Government but has only such executive powers 
as  the  chairperson  may  authorize.  All  officers  and  employees  of  the  Pourashava  are 
subordinate  to  chief  executive  officer.    Municipal  ordinances,  however,  contain  numerous 
clauses under which the Central Government can give directions to municipalities. In fact, only a 
few amendments have been made to the Pourashava Ordinance in the last 10 years, and even

to local governments.  
 
C.  Urban Sector Policy Framework 
 
5.  Although the Government of Bangladesh has long been aware of both the rapid pace of 
urbanization in the country and the associated physical, economic, and social problems, it has 
not yet adopted an explicit urban policy. However, a number of government documents and 
other initiatives have from time to time indicated the policy thinking of the Government with 
regard to urbanization and urban development. The National Report on Human Settlements 
submitted to the United Nations Habitat I Conference held at Vancouver in Canada in 1976 
came  close  to  a  policy  statement  on  human  settlements  and  urbanization  in  Bangladesh. 
Besides this, the various five-year plan documents prepared between 1973 and 1998 also 
indicated some policy direction.  
 
6.  Overall, however, the formal planning documents have sidetracked urban development.. 
For instance, almost none of the plans developed through successive five-year plan exercises 
were ever implemented. In 1991, the Planning Commission abandoned the sequence of five-
year plans and instead spent a lot of time to issue a 15-year Participatory Perspective Plan to 
be supplemented with detailed Annual Development Programs. However, the Plan was never 
finalized, and the five-year planning process was reestablished. The Fifth Five-Year Plan has 
followed  more  or  less  the  earlier  policies  and  emphasized  decentralization  development. 
However, investments have continued to be concentrated in the largest cities, Dhaka and 
Chittagong. On the other hand, a number of parallel developments outside the five-year plan 
exercises have emphasized urbanization and the urban sector. The Report of the Task Force on 
Social Implications of Urbanization prepared in 1991 at the behest of the interim government of 
the time made an elaborate statement on urban policy and poverty reduction. This report, 
however,  was  not  approved  by  the  new  Government  and  therefore  not  considered  for 
implementation.  
7.  Subsequently, the National Housing Policy (1993), the Bangladesh Urban and Shelter 
Sector Review (1993), the Bangladesh Urban Sector National Program Document (1994), the 
Bangladesh National Habitat II Report (1996), and the recent Bangladesh National Habitat II 
Istanbul+5 Report (2001) have all underscored the most important role urbanization can play in 
national development. All these documents have spelled out policy directions and even action 
plans  for  achieving  a  balanced  development  process.  The  National  Housing  Policy  is  an 
officially approved document, and so are the 1996 Habitat II and 2001 Istanbul+5 Report. The 
Urban Management Policy Statements (1994 and 1999) prepared by the Ministry of Local 
Government (jointly with the Asian Development Bank and the World Bank) emphasized that all 
Pourashavas should have adequate personnel and financial strength, provide and maintain 
basic infrastructure facilities, prepare and implement land use plans, address poverty, ensure 
participation and involve the private sector.

SUBPROJECT COMPONENT SELECTION CRITERIA 
 
1.  The selection of subproject components will be based on the following criteria (i) suitable 
technical options have been explored; (ii) a least-cost comparison of technically feasible options 
has been prepared; (iii) maps, plans, and details at a reasonable scale showing the location, 
scope, and scale of the component, and a preliminary cost estimate have been prepared; (iv) an 
implementation  plan  proposing  responsibilities  of  the  project  implementation  unit  for 
construction and operation and maintenance (O&M) has been prepared; (v) environmental 
impacts have been examined, mitigation measures have  been proposed, and assurances have 
been  obtained  for  necessary  approvals;  (vi)  community  views  have  been  sought  and 
incorporated  in  the  component,  and  social  impacts  (including  resettlement  and  indigenous 
peoples issues) have been addressed; (vii) preparatory work has been completed to acquire 
necessary land and rights-of-way; (viii) the subproject component conforms to adopted town 
plans,  road  plans,  and  regulations;  (ix)  the  Pourashava  has  the  financial,  technical,  and 
personnel resources necessary for O&M of the subproject component; and (x) opportunities for 
public-private partnerships have been examined for subproject implementation and operation. 
 
2.  Additional criteria for selection of subproject component that are specific to each of the 
potential seven subsectors under each subproject are described below. 
 
A.  Roads and Bridges 
 
3.  The selection criteria for road and bridge components are as follows: (i) a completed 
land development or traffic survey indicates a need for improvement to accommodate the 
existing potential traffic; (ii) the cost of O&M can be met; and (iii) the component has an 
economic internal rate of return (EIRR) greater than 12%, based on savings in vehicle operating 
costs, accidents, and personal travel time for business purposes in the case of existing roads, 
and on the basis of economic development potential for new roads. 
 
B.  Water Supply 
 
4.  The selection criteria for water supply components are as follows: (i) a user-needs and 
willingness-to-pay survey confirms the need for the component; (ii) the availability of required 
raw water has been confirmed; (iii) water tariffs are set at a level that generates sufficient 
revenue to cover the cost of O&M, and the higher of either depreciation and interest or debt 
service for the component; and (iv) the implementation of any tubewell works will be strictly in 
line with the Government’s guidelines and standards for the development of deep tubewells. 
 
C.  Municipal Facilities 
 
1.  Truck and Bus Terminals 
 
5.  The following are the selection criteria for truck and bus terminals: (i) a completed traffic 
survey shows that truck and bus traffic is sufficient to require a new or upgraded truck or bus 
terminals; (ii) a suitable plot allocation plan exists covering the price or lease terms for the sites 
and the process for selection of beneficiaries; and (iii) the subproject component has a financial 
internal rate of return (FIRR) in excess of the weighted average cost of capital, and will generate 
sufficient revenue to cover the cost of O&M for the facility and debt service.

36  Appendix 8 
 
2.  Public Markets 
 
6.  Selection criteria for public markets are the following: (i) a survey has demonstrated the 
need for a new or extended market and has estimated the number of stalls required, their size, 
and the likely rents to be charged for them; (ii) a suitable plot allocation plan exists covering the 
price or lease terms for the sites and the process for allocation of plots; and (iii) the component 
has an FIRR in excess of the weighted average cost of capital, and will generate sufficient 
revenue to cover the cost of O&M for the facility and debt service. 
 
D.  Drainage 
 
7.  The following are the selection criteria for drainage component: (i) a completed survey 
reveals frequent flooding, waterlogging, landslides, disruption of traffic, unsanitary conditions, or 
damage to roads and property; (ii) sufficient resources and systems are available to support 
O&M for the component; and (iii) the component has an EIRR of 12% or higher, based on an 
analysis of property damage, and personal inconvenience and suffering that will be avoided 
through implementation of the subproject. 
 
E.  Low-Cost Sanitation 
 
8.  Selection criteria for low-cost sanitation components are the following: (i) a completed 
user-needs  and  willingness-to-pay  survey  confirms  the  need  for  the  component;  (ii)  the 
beneficiaries are willing and able to provide labor and other in-kind support to construct the 
latrines and to build the superstructures out of their own resources; (iii) the Pourashava is willing 
and able to provide required advisory assistance to the beneficiaries; (iv) suitable arrangements 
have been made for O&M − in the case of public latrines, the Pourashava will appoint a person 
or persons to be responsible for the maintenance of the latrines; and (v) users will be charged 
fees sufficient to cover the cost of O&M for the latrines. 
 
F.  Solid Waste Management 
 
9.  Selection  criteria  for  solid  waste  management  components  are  as  follows:  (i)  the 
component has a FIRR, which is greater than the weighted average cost of capital; and (ii) 
incremental revenue is obtained from either direct user charges or rates to meet the cost of 
O&M for the solid waste facilities and services. Where the opportunity exists for composting of 
solid  waste,  its  implementation  should  be  clearly  defined  in  the  proposals  for  solid  waste 
components. 
 
G.  Slum Improvement 
 
10.  Slum improvement components have the following selection criteria: (i) compilation of an 
official list of households actually occupying the site; (ii) completion of the requisite physical 
surveys of the site and social surveys of the resident population; (iii) completion of a detailed 
feasibility  study  and  selection  of  an  upgrading  approach  based  on  technical  and  financial 
suitability for local conditions, affordability, and resident desires; (iv) formation of an active 
community  development  committee  to  ensure  maximum  community  participation  in  both 
implementation  and  maintenance  of  the  upgrading  components;  (v)  certification  that  the 
proposed land use for special areas has the full approval of the Pourashava and the local 
community; and (vi) beneficiaries undertake to make in-kind and financial contributions to meet 
the cost of O&M for the component, and a system is designed to implement this commitment.

discussions with the minister of Local Government, Rural Development and Cooperatives, it 
was  suggested  that  the  Project  would  provide  the  framework  for  such  a  committee.  As 
stipulated during the discussions with the minister, the activities of this committee may include, 
among others, the preparation of the National Urban Sector Policy for cabinet approval, review

sustainable urban development.

improving collection of holding taxes from public and private sector entities as

Contribution of the sector/subsector to reducing poverty in Bangladesh: 
 
The incidence of poverty, as measured by the costs of basic needs poverty line, fell from 58.8% in 1992 to 49.8% in 
2000. A sector breakdown of poverty shows that progress on reducing poverty incidence was almost equal across 
urban and rural areas: the urban headcount rate declined from 44.9% to 36.6% (by 8.3%) while rural poverty 
declined from 61.2% to 53.0% (by 8.2%). However, the moderate reduction in urban poverty during the last decade 
was accompanied by a notable increase in urban income inequality, as the Gini coefficient increased from 0.398 to 
0.452. 
 
The situations have been somewhat different in the case of absolute numbers of the poor in urban and rural areas. 
In 1992, the number of urban poor was 6.5 million while the total urban population was 14.6 million. This then 
increased to 9.3 million in 2000. Thus there was at least a 43% growth of the urban poor population during the last 
decade. The rural poor population, on the other hand, recorded a decline in its absolute number from 57.6 million to 
53.5 million. The principal reason behind this phenomenon is the large-scale shift of the rural population to the 
urban areas in the hope of better economic opportunities. The labor force in urban towns is composed primarily of 
migrants. It is also dominated by youth. The urban poor in the slums have very low levels of education and hardly 
any skills. About 40% of the population aged 5-15 years are not attending school. Sixty to eighty percent of the 
urban labor force is in the informal sector depending on the size of the city. Female migrants in small towns lack 
employment opportunities in both the formal and informal sector. An increasing number of urban poor especially the 
youth, are being employed in socially unproductive or unacceptable occupations, like extortion, begging, and 
prostitution. 
 
If the current trend of migration continues, the urban poor will increase to 25-30% of the total country's poor by 
2020, if not more. This points to the growing need to address adverse impacts of unplanned and uncontrolled 
urbanization and promote balanced urban development. In particular, the Asian Development Bank’s (ADB) urban 
sector strategy in Bangladesh has recognized the strategic importance of secondary towns in the urbanization 
process, and the need to promote them to lead a sound and balanced urban development. The concentration of 
population and activities in a few metropolitan areas has aggravated urban environmental conditions in the absence 
of adequate capacities to manage urban growth. Recognizing diseconomies of congestion and deteriorating living 
conditions of the urban poor in metropolitan cities, ADB has already provided five loans totaling $208 million for 
urban infrastructure projects in secondary towns since the start of its operations in Bangladesh in the late 1980s. 
The proposed Project will further contribute to the achievements made so far by improving urban governance and 
infrastructure services in secondary towns.  
 
 
B.  Poverty Analysis      Proposed Classification: Poverty Intervention 
Under the Project, low-income families were identified based on their monthly incomes. The households with 
monthly incomes of less than Tk4,700 ($81) are classified as poor and those with monthly incomes of less than 
Tk3,400 ($59) as hard-core poor. The household survey shows that about 35% of the population in the project 
towns are classified as poor and around 15% as hard-core poor.  
 
The direct impact of the Project on poverty reduction is employment generation arising from the construction phase. 
The unskilled labor content of the Project is estimated at Tk298 million, equivalent to 11,160 person-years. While 
the gender ratio of unskilled labor employment is difficult to estimate, it is anticipated that at least one third of the 
unskilled labor person-years will be destined for women. The Gender Action Plan under the Project also assures 
that women workers will get fair wages relative to the male workers.  
 
The Project will also benefit the poor through direct support for environmental improvement and income generation. 
The integrated package of services (low-cost sanitation, microcredit, and community-based waste management, 
etc.) to be provided will have a significant impact on the living conditions of poor people.  Raising environmental 
conditions will also mitigate the incidence of waterborne and vectored diseases, with consequent reduction in 
mortality and morbidity rates. Currently, environmental conditions in the Project towns are grossly unsatisfactory, 
and fewer than 50% have access to sanitary facilities. Wastes from community latrines, where provided, frequently 
contaminate the groundwater. During monsoon times, conditions are particularly unhygienic.

ECONOMIC AND FINANCIAL ANALYSES OF TYPICAL SUBPROJECTS 
 
1.  Economic internal rates of return (EIRRs) and financial internal rates of return (FIRRs), 
as appropriate, were prepared for representative subprojects in accordance with the Asian 
Development Bank’s (ADB) Framework for the Economic and Financial Appraisal of Urban 
Development Sector Projects. EIRRs were prepared for roads, drainage, and slum improvement 
components,  and  FIRRs  for  water  supply,  and  municipal  facilities.  The  evaluations  are 
summarized in Tables A14.1 and A14.2. 
 
2.  The basic assumptions used in economic analysis are that (i) economic costs are based 
on June 2002 prices; (ii) both capital cost and operation and maintenance (O&M) cost estimates 
were apportioned into traded and nontraded components and labor; (iii) using a domestic price 
numeraire, financial prices (based on June 2002 prices and reduced by duties and taxes) were 
converted  to  economic  prices  by  a  shadow  exchange  rate  factor  of  1.05  for  traded  cost 
components and 1.0 for nontraded cost components; (iv) a shadow wage rate factor of 0.87 was 
used for skilled and 0.67 for unskilled labor to reflect unemployment and underemployment; (v) 
annual  O&M  cost  is  assumed  to  be  0.5%  of  capital  cost,  and  periodic  (every  6  years) 
maintenance cost 3% of capital cost; and (vi) subprojects were assessed for a period that 
include project implementation and 20 years of benefits, with no allowance for the residual value 
of assets at the end of the evaluation period. 
 
3.  Financial analyses are conducted in June 2002 prices taking into account incremental 
O&M. Basic assumptions used in the computation of the FIRR include the following: (i) all 
revenues and costs are expressed at constant June 2002 prices on an incremental basis; (ii) 
project  investment  costs  were  derived  from  the  estimated  base  costs  and  physical 
contingencies, but without considering price contingencies and interest during construction; and 
(iii) capital expenditures are recorded at the time when they are incurred, while interest and 
depreciation are excluded. 
 
A.  Drainage   
 
4.  Under  phase  1,  primary  and  secondary  drains  of  83.35  kilometers  (km)  in  21 
Pourashavas will be upgraded and extended at a base cost of Tk340 million ($5.87 million).  
The proposed rehabilitation of the drainage system will help reduce the incidence of flooding in 
a  catchment  area  of  292  hectares  benefiting  71,695  properties.  Economic  evaluation  was 
prepared  for  all  schemes  within  a  Pourashava  because  linkages  between  drains  result  in 
benefits that are not always discrete to an individual scheme. The improved drainage network 
will help reduce damage to houses, household goods, crops, and business activity in the areas 
presently experiencing inundation. The improvements will further result in increased value of 
land in the catchment area. 
 
5.  For economic benefit, the annual flood damage to movable and immovable household 
property was quantified based on the findings of a socioeconomic survey carried out under the 
PPTA.  The  annual  average  damage  cost  was  estimated  between  Tk1,400  and  Tk2,715 
depending on the type of the property. The number of properties is based on the Pourashavas 
estimates  of  the  properties  expected  to  be  benefited  within  the  catchments  area  of  each 
proposed scheme. Allowance is made for the unit benefit to rise by 2% per annum in the future, 
as against the forecast growth of around 5% in the gross domestic product per capita.

6.  The economic evaluations, which also take into account the incremental maintenance 
costs, estimated the overall EIRR at 34.0 percent (individual EIRRs range from 12.1% to 
73.7%). However, actual EIRR could be even higher, given that the rehabilitated drainage 
system will generate additional benefits that are difficult to quantify: (i) reduced damage to motor 
vehicles and public infrastructure such as roads; (ii) reduced loss of personal income when 
employment is disrupted; (iii) reduced waterlogging from rainwater into residential areas (the 
stagnant and contaminated water becomes the source of mosquito breeding); (iv) reduced 
degradation of urban environmental conditions; (v) reduced incidence of waterborne diseases 
within the community, which would result in reduction of childhood prenatal and postnatal illness 
and mortality rates; and (vi) reduced disruption to personal and community life caused by slow 
dispersal of storm water, etc. 
 
B.  Roads 
 
7.  Investments  are  aimed  at  improvement  to  a  variety  of  surfaces  and  alignments  of 
existing  roads,  plus  some  road  widening.  There  is  no  new  road  construction.  In  all,  293 
individual schemes have been submitted by 21 Pourashavas for inclusion under phase 1. The 
cost of all except four individual schemes is well below the ADB’s cut-off rate for analysis of 
$200,000 (Tk11.6 million).  
 
8.  While submitting the proposal for the road rehabilitation schemes, the Pourashavas were 
asked to carry out a 12-hour traffic count to support the need for the upgradation. Although the 
Pourashavas have submitted a broad traffic count for each scheme, their reliability cannot be 
fully assessed. The economic analysis therefore has been carried out for the four schemes 
costing  above  $200,000,  and  a  few  other  representative  schemes  to  demonstrate  their 
feasibility.  
 
9.  The improved road network will result in reduction in traffic congestion and accidents, 
savings in travel time and vehicle operating costs, and safer conditions for pedestrians and non-
motorized traffic. The main objective of investment in urban roads is to reduce user costs of 
different vehicle types, which means the reduction of cost to the travelers in moving from one 
location to another.  
 
10.  For benefit analysis, vehicle operating costs have been classified into the following 
groups:  (i)  distance-dependent  costs,  which  vary  directly  with  distances  covered  (e.g., 
consumption of fuel, lubricants, wear and tear of tires, and repair and maintenance); (ii) speed-
dependent costs, which arise out of low speed because of poor/bad condition of roads; and (iii) 
time-dependent costs. 
 
11.  In the secondary towns, the most prevalent vehicle type is the rickshaw, and these have 
therefore been considered for benefit calculation. The difference in the time saved due to 
increased speed under "without” and “with" project situations was allotted a time value. In the 
without project situation, pedalling 1 km requires 12.5 minutes, whereas under the improved 
situation  the  required  time  would  be  reduced  to  7.5  minutes/km.  This  time  saved  after 
improvement would be available for additional trips, resulting in benefits. The saving has been 
converted into a benefit assuming that a rickshaw puller charges Tk3 per km.   
 
12.  The individual EIRRs assessed for the selected road schemes range between 13.4% 
and 74.8% above the economic opportunity cost of capital, which is 12% for Bangladesh. The 
sensitivity analysis also indicates the robustness of the EIRR with respect to the changes in 
economic benefits and costs.

C.  Water Supply 
 
13.  A water supply component under the Project will generally involve rehabilitation of and 
extension to existing systems. Therefore, the incremental volume sold will be calculated by 
subtracting the estimated existing volume sold from the projected annual volume sold. To 
assess the financial viability of a typical water supply component, a financial evaluation was 
prepared for the water supply component in Lakshmipur. The capacity of the existing production 
wells in the Pourashava is approximately 2,500 cubic meters per day or about 33% of the daily 
requirements, estimated at 7,500 cubic meters per day.  In terms of geographical coverage, the 
present water distribution network serves 2,280 out of 12,200 households. In view of the rapidly 
deteriorating situation, it is proposed to construct two production tubewells, a treatment plant, an 
overhead tank, and 8 km of distribution pipelines of 100-250 millimeters diameter at a total base 
cost of Tk36.1 million. 
 
14.  The subproject will be funded as 70% loan and 20% grant from the Government. The 
Pourashava will meet the remaining 10% from its own resources. The loan portion will carry 
interest at 7% with an amortization period of 20 years including the 5-year grace period.  
 
15.  For revenue calculation, it is assumed that the water tariff will rise in real terms by 5% 
during the FY2003. Upon completion of the new scheme, the tariff will increase in real term by 
15% in the year of commissioning and thereafter by 5% on an annual basis. The incremental 
operating  cost  of  the  scheme  is  estimated  at  7%  of  the  cost  of  the  scheme.  Based  the 
incremental revenue and costs, the base FIRR is calculated as 10.3% compared with the 
weighted average cost of capital of 6.1%. Sensitivity tests indicate that the FIRR is most 
sensitive to the decrease in revenue.   
 
16.  The field visit to the town revealed that the domestic users of the subconnections are 
willing to pay more than the current water tariff payment of Tk150 per month provided the quality 
of  service  is  improved.  The  experience  from  other  externally  funded  projects  (e.g.,  the 
Netherlands assistance program) shows that households were willing to pay even when the 
charges were increased by 150% to a maximum 250%. When the tariff increase was 100%, the 
collection efficiency reached as high as 79%. An affordability analysis shows that overall the 
water supply charges are affordable, taking into account the low level of even median-income 
households. The percentage of median income required to pay water charges would be no 
more than 4-5%.   
 
D.  Solid Waste Disposal 
 
17.  The solid waste service is paid for through the conservancy element of the holding tax, 
and the maximum levy permitted under Pourashava Ordinance is 7% of the eligible tax base. 
Since all property holders must pay the tax, there are no incremental users of the service, and 
therefore no FIRR can be calculated. Instead, a cost recovery analysis has been carried out for 
all Pourashavas to assess the adequacy of revenues to recover the cost associated with solid 
waste service (except for Mehepur, which does not levy the conservancy tax). Revenues are 
estimated by the conservancy element of the holding tax projections.  
 
18.  While it is desirable that revenues should cover all costs, including depreciation and 
recurrent costs for O&M, it is anticipated that only eight Pourashavas will achieve full cost 
recovery without a significant improvement of tax revenues. Since the poor cost recovery is 
related to general problems with tax assessment and collection, during project implementation,

E.  Municipal Facilities 
 
19.  Financial  analyses  for  municipal  facilities  (e.g.,  transport  terminals,  markets,  and 
slaughterhouses) are prepared in consideration of the Local Government Division’s directive 
that, while Pourashavas may provide these services, they should be operated by the private 
sector.  Revenues for these activities will be derived from leasing the facilities, and are based on 
investment recovery over 5 years, plus a 2% real annual increase of rental fee. Costs are 
associated with regular O&M of the facilities, estimated at 2.5% of fixed asset gross book value. 
The implementation period of the municipal facilities varies significantly: blocks of public toilets 
can be leased immediately upon completion; the construction of slaughterhouses will take one 
year, truck terminals 2 years, and bus terminals 3 years based on the experience with the 
Secondary Towns Infrastructure Development Project  II.   
 
20.  For markets, it is assumed that Pourashavas will lease out shops to individuals rather 
than to a single leaseholder. Four different development levels are proposed (41, 62, 75, and 83 
shops), depending on the size of the Pourashava. It is estimated that 60% of the total floor area 
will be leased out, with each shop having a floor area of 11.24 square meters. The rental per 
square meter is Tk200 per month, with a real annual increase of 2%. Additional income will be 
obtained from trade licenses, assessed at Tk500 per annum. O&M is 2.5% of fixed assets.  
 
21.  Financial evaluations were prepared to develop different types of municipal facilities: The 
FIRR is estimated at 12.9% for a bus terminal in Narsinghdi, 19.1% for a slaughterhouse in 
Narayanganji, and 14.5% for markets in Mehepur.   
 
F.  Slum Improvement 
 
22.  The  slum  improvement  component  consists  of  provision  of  tubewells,  pit  latrines, 
dustbins and street lighting, plus construction of footpaths and microdrainage. The scope of the 
physical investments in each slum area is based on the number of low-income households. 
Since most activities under the slum improvement component are aimed at reducing morbidity 
levels through the introduction of higher sanitation standards, one of the benefits could be 
health expenditure savings. However, since family health expenditure data collected by the 
socioeconomic survey are not entirely reliable, benefits are taken in the form of productivity 
gains, quantified as follows: (i) 10 working days equivalent gained by the wage earner, (ii) 10 
working days equivalent gained by the housekeeper from reduced child morbidity levels, and (iii) 
30 minutes per day saved by women due to the closer proximity of clean piped water supplies.  
For economic analysis, it is conservatively assumed that the economic value of the nonwage 
earner’s time is 20% of the wage earner’s income. Despite this relatively modest evaluation of 
productivity gains, the base EIRRs for all 22 towns were estimated above the cut-off rate of 
12%.
